flags.evidence:
Minimum wage data are not fetched from the stated Vaghul-Zipperer database; instead, a hand-entered table of a few values is used and a full 2010–2022 panel is created by linear interpolation from a single endpoint (mw_2022) and a first_treat_year. This constructs synthetic policy paths that likely do not match actual statutory minimum wages (which change discretely, often annually, sometimes mid-year and with indexing/localities). Because the minimum wage variable is the treatment, this is effectively fabricated/constructed key explanatory data and can materially change estimates.: state_mw_changes <- tribble(
  ~state, ~state_name, ~first_treat_year, ~mw_2022,
  # Early movers (already above federal by 2010)
  6,  "California", 2008, 15.00,
  ...
  55, "Wisconsin", 2005, 7.25  # Tied to federal
)
...
mutate(
  # Interpolate state MW from first treat year to 2022
  state_mw = case_when(
    is.na(first_treat_year) ~ fed_mw,
    year < first_treat_year ~ fed_mw,
    year >= first_treat_year ~ fed_mw + (mw_2022 - fed_mw) * (year - first_treat_year) / (2022 - first_treat_year),
    TRUE ~ fed_mw
  ),
  eff_mw = pmax(state_mw, fed_mw)
)

The manuscript claims minimum wage data come from the Vaghul-Zipperer database with monthly effective rates, but the code provides neither a download step nor a citation-linked raw file; instead it uses an undocumented, partial, hand-coded 'simplified panel' and interpolates. There is no verifiable provenance for the policy series used in estimation.: # Part 1: Minimum Wage Data (Vaghul-Zipperer database)
...
# Create minimum wage panel from DOL data
# State MW data compiled from DOL and NCSL sources
...
# Key state MW increases above federal (simplified panel)
# Source: DOL State Minimum Wages chart and NCSL compilations
state_mw_changes <- tribble(

Key descriptive figure inputs (mean/min/max minimum wage series, cumulative count of states above federal MW, and cohort histogram counts) are hard-coded as literal vectors rather than computed from the minimum wage data used in analysis. This allows figures to be made consistent with narrative regardless of underlying data and breaks reproducibility/auditability.: mw_data <- data.frame(
  year = years,
  fed_mw = 7.25,
  mean_mw = c(7.25, 7.27, 7.32, 7.40, 7.55, 7.75, 8.05, 8.45, 8.90, 9.35, 9.85, 10.35, 10.85),
  min_mw = rep(7.25, 13),
  max_mw = c(8.55, 8.67, 9.04, 9.32, 9.50, 10.00, 10.50, 11.00, 12.00, 13.25, 14.00, 15.00, 16.28)
)
...
states_data <- data.frame(
  year = 2010:2022,
  n_above = c(15, 15, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 29, 30, 30, 30)
)
...
cohort_data <- data.frame(
  cohort_year = c(2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019),
  n_states = c(1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 2, 2, 1, 1)
)

A reported-looking heterogeneity figure is built from explicitly hard-coded ATT/SE values marked 'Illustrative' rather than estimated from model outputs. If included in the paper (or if a reader cannot tell it's illustrative), it constitutes non-computed results in the output artifacts.: het_data <- data.frame(
  group = c("Low-Wage (Main)", "Low-Education", "All 65+", "High-Education (Placebo)"),
  att = c(-0.015, -0.012, -0.005, 0.002),  # Illustrative
  se = c(0.006, 0.005, 0.003, 0.004)
)

The manuscript states the analysis uses ACS 2010–2022; the code fetches ACS PUMS for 2010–2023 (and labels the script as CPS). This can change the panel and reported sample years unless later explicitly filtered everywhere. The mismatch also weakens reproducibility because the data pull does not align with the stated sample period.: # 01_fetch_data.R
# Fetch CPS data and minimum wage data
...
# Part 2: CPS MORG Data via Census API
...
# CPS MORG is not directly available via Census API
# We'll use ACS PUMS as alternative
...
years <- 2010:2023
for (y in years) {
  df <- fetch_acs_pums(y)
}

The manuscript defines the primary analysis group as low-education elderly (HS or less) specifically to avoid occupation/industry being observed only for employed respondents. In contrast, the code defines 'low_wage_likely' using industry/occupation indicators (INDP/OCCP), which are typically missing for non-employed individuals in ACS PUMS. This can induce selection/composition differences and directly contradicts the stated rationale and sample definition in the paper.: low_wage_likely = (hs_or_less & (retail | food_service | service_occ | admin_support))
...
# Low-wage likely sample (main analysis sample)
cps_lowwage <- cps_clean %>%
  filter(low_wage_likely)

Subgroup employment rates are computed using logical indexing on variables (e.g., service_occ, low_wage_likely) that may be NA for non-employed people if ACS does not record OCCP/INDP for them. With `na.rm=TRUE`, this can unintentionally drop non-employed observations from denominators for these subgroup rates, inflating employment rates and potentially affecting treatment effects if missingness differs by treatment/time. This is especially concerning for the 'low_wage_likely' outcome used as primary in several scripts/tables.: emp_rate_lowedu = weighted.mean(employed[hs_or_less], weight[hs_or_less], na.rm = TRUE),
...
emp_rate_service = weighted.mean(employed[service_occ], weight[service_occ], na.rm = TRUE),
...
emp_rate_lowwage = weighted.mean(employed[low_wage_likely], weight[low_wage_likely], na.rm = TRUE)

The manuscript's pre-trend test is described as using both treated and never-treated states with year fixed effects (EverTreated × time). The code instead restricts to treated states only and includes only state fixed effects (no year FE), estimating a within-treated linear trend in event time. This does not test differential trends versus controls as described and can miss confounding common shocks in the pre-period.: # Restrict to pre-treatment period for treated states
df_pretrends <- state_year %>%
  filter(ever_treated) %>%
  filter(year < first_treat_year)
...
pretrend_test <- feols(
  emp_rate_lowwage ~ years_to_treat | state,
  data = df_pretrends,
  cluster = ~state
)

summary.one_liner: fabricated data; unclear provenance; hard-coded results
summary.executive_summary: The code does not obtain minimum wage data from the stated Vaghul–Zipperer database; instead it relies on a small hand-entered table and then fabricates a full 2010–2022 monthly panel by linear interpolation, with no download step or provenance-linked raw file. Several headline figures are not reproducible because their inputs are hard-coded as literal vectors (including “illustrative” ATT/SE values for a heterogeneity plot) rather than computed from the underlying data and model outputs. The data pipeline also conflicts with the paper’s description by pulling ACS PUMS for 2010–2023 (and even labeling the script as CPS), introducing mismatched sample years relative to the claimed 2010–2022 ACS analysis.
